Squidsoft.Net InterMOO Message Board System
--
Subject: DIATRIBE OF FURY: THE FALL OF THE AEU
Author: Gordon Balk
Posted: Fri Nov 25 21:31:35 2016 UTC
--
An Incredibly Harsh Breakdown Of Current Events Within The Alliance Of
ExtraSolar Unions
--
First a disclaimer: This entire AEU 'arc' is not one that the staff set in
motion or planned. This story arc has -IN ITS ENTIRETY- been set up, continued
and reinforced by you, the AEU players themselves.  All the staff have done is
have NPCs and the game world respond logically to repeated player action.
--
A GIANT'S REACH SHORTENS
--
With the conclusion to the opening Catalyst story arc, things calmed down
dramatically - combat was no longer a near-constant thing, invasions slowed, and
the playerbase were able to take a breath and enjoy their victory.  The AEU,
long known in SC Classic as the alliance for exploration, began to reclaim its
title with ships and upgrades superior to the other alliances for the purpose
of, well, exploring.  For some time, AEU starships and upgrades were simply the
best, by far, for distance travel and exploration.  This was intentional as the
AEU focus WAS exploration.
That's not to say that exploration was impossible for non-AEU players; in fact
much of the early exploration was done by non-AEU players using non-AEU
technology - starships and upgrades that were inferior to AEU versions, in fact.
 It appeared that though they had the best options available, the AEU players
were content to allow non-AEU players to do the bulk of the exploring using
non-AEU technology, perhaps being part of the crew but almost never initiating
exploration trips by themselves.
Two early expeditions WERE led by one AEU player, but after that this player
became content to merely join exploration missions rather than lead them - and
as things continued it became clear that the AEU playerbase as a whole had no
real interest in exploration.  Yes, they continued to SAY they wanted to explore
- but no one actually went out and did it.  
We had the AEU government (IE, us) suggest, we had them cajole, we had them
directly request that AEU pilots initiate and lead expeditions.  And still no
one initiated any exploration trips - instead many of the AEU players began to
focus on keeping temporary beacons online.  So as time went on, the alliances
who contained the players who DID explore gradually overtook the AEU in
exploration technology, while the AEU began to release technology more suited to
the tasks that AEU players were beginning to actively involving themselves.
The AEU was no longer the alliance of exploration, but of maintenance -
completely via player action.
--
DISSOLUTION OF TRUST
--
After the Catalyst arc the three main alliances (League, AEU, Fringe) had ended
up fairly close due to the near-extermination of humanity.  As time went on the
three alliances (through the actions of the players) grew closer still and ended
up with full alliances in an attempt to stop piracy and other conflict.  As
expected, the Mutuality was the outlier - originally (after an initial stumbling
block) the Mutuality had had relatively strong ties to the AEU and Fringe. 
However, as time went on events both staff and player initiated caused tension
between the Mutuality and both AEU and Fringe, leaving lasting scars and giving
the League a chance to swoop in and forge closer ties to the Mutuality.
And then the AEU pilot corps unilaterally decided to break diplomatic ties with
all the other alliances, remaining neutral to them all.  This was unexpected -
with the sheer amount of support for it from the AEU playerbase surprising us -
but the AEU players had spoken: the AEU would go it alone as the AEU playerbase
continued to reinforce their desire to separate from the other alliances.
The AEU had become increasingly isolationist, purely through player choice.
--
THE PRICE OF INACTION
--
One of the largest problems we have had in Star Conquest is the lack of active
decision-making by the playerbase.  While this is also an issue with major
plotlines and the playerbase as a whole, we will focus here on purely AEU
events, most of which were primarily player-driven and (unfortunately) far more
negative in outcome than events involving players from other alliances.
The Slavers
--
At one point, a non-AEU expedition discovered the unreg faction called the Feng
Wo Collective and several of their trading stations.  They learned a bit about
Feng Wo cultural mores and attitudes and took that information back home. 
Another expedition of other players (led by a League player, but with several
AEU players present) decided to find the Feng Wo and see what they had to offer.
When this second crew reached Feng Wo space, they brought their security robots
onto the station with them.  At the time, we considered having the Feng Wo react
badly to this and treat it as a hostile action; after all, this was a crew of
regs - people known to hate unregs - who had arrived in a powerful warship, and
had now brought out several weapons platforms.  But in the end we decided that
while that might have been the most logical approach it would have been a little
extreme, so instead we had the Feng Wo confiscate the robots and began what we
thought was a fun, minor mini-event to let them acquire the funds necessary to
pay the fine to get their robots back.
Without bogging this down with detail, suffice to say that the players decided
to take an unnecessary route to maximise profit rather than simply get their
robots back, and it involved buying and selling slaves.  When this information
came back to the AEU playerbase as a whole, they refused to take any action and
tacitly supported the actions of the 'slavers' by saying it 'wasn't that bad'
and that as they had apologised, it should be forgotten and people should 'move
on'.  
We have seen people comment both ICly and OOCly about the difference between the
response to the AEU and to the League.  The primary reason for the different
responses is that the League players immediately condemned the actions of the
lone League pilot involved, then worked fast to contact the Mutuality to find
out more information and took steps to both find the slaves ICly and to have the
government deal with their single League slaver.  In comparison, the AEU
playerbase spent their time telling other players to leave the AEU slavers alone
since they had 'apologised' and then telling people they would do something and
then not doing it.
This took alliance relations further down and had the AEU as a whole appear in a
worse position - in the end the AEU government (IE, the staff) had to force the
issue in order to get the AEU playerbase to acknowledge that slavery is in fact
bad.
Negotiation With Evil
--
A while after this, the Voice at the time was convinced to attempt to
re-establish diplomatic relations with the Mutuality.  However, this Voice was
known to make very public anti-Mutuality and anti-Mutuality Council comments,
even going so far as to call the Council itself 'evil'.  During the negotiations
the Voice was insulting, derogatory and ultimately made relations worse than
before.
When that term ended, the next Voice stated they would attempt to undo the
damage - yet listened to the previous Voice's suggestions when they attempted to
communicate with the Mutuality and in the end decided that it was not worth
continuing the effort.
The Voice after THAT made big claims that they would re-establish relations with
the Mutuality, yet made not a single effort to do so.
This was all very public at the time and made the AEU even more of a laughing
stock.
All Roads Lead to Helios
--
Another exploration trip led by someone who was not AEU.  Through a few minor
errors, an Outsider patrol stumbled over them and destroyed the ship.  This by
itself would have been frustrating for the players, but ultimately a footnote -
except for the fact that the AEU players who were part of the trip decided to
redirect the escape pod to Helios; a place that in-game is required to remain
hidden from the Outsiders at all costs.
This started a minor event which culminated in the Mutuality being forced to
make a choice - sacrifice thousands to potentially save millions, or take a risk
and save everyone... but sacrifice their only possible escape plan if things go
wrong.  
By itself, this would merely have had the Mutuality once again lower its opinion
of the AEU - which was already at rock bottom.  However, the AEU Voice at the
time decided to throw under a bus the AEU player who had redirected the pod -
they had taken a trip to Feng Wo space, and the AEU Voice suggested to the AEU
government that they were fleeing, implying that they had redirected the pod
intentionally and were now trying to evade consequences.
The only realistic response to this was for the AEU government to send a
military task force to capture the AEU player - except the AEU player was
already returning to AEU space; it was a shopping trip, not an attempt to
escape.  This resulted in yet another Mutuality/AEU diplomatic incident and had
the AEU once again lose face on an interstellar scale because of player
decisions.
A Man of Wealth and Taste
--
Most players are aware of the Allied Pirates; once-registered individuals who
have banded together under the banner of one Mister Kelsey, a mysterious yet
apparently refined and intellectual gentleman who has major issues with the
alliances - especially the EAOS.
Mister Kelsey occasionally adds his voice to discussion on General
Communications, often entering into discourse with the civilian pilots - much to
the chagrin of the alliance governments and the joy of the media.
A relatively new AEU player had convinced the AEU playerbase that they should be
Voice.  They did not know much about the political climate, about the current
situation with enemies and allies, or anything else.  They also did not see it
necessary to learn about these things, either - once again a small but important
negative incident for the AEU even without what followed.
After getting lost in deep space, another new AEU player and friend of the Voice
was rescued by Mister Kelsey - as he is wont to do now and then for reasons of
his own.  The player did not know who Mister Kelsey was and did not ask anyone
via Communicator who he was, either - but they were on the phone to the AEU
Voice, who also did not ask who Mister Kelsey was.  All they saw was 'Allied
Pirate', which should have given enough of a hint.  Instead, they expressed an
interest in meeting Mister Kelsey in person and an agreement was reached -
resulting in them being taken to the Allied Pirates base.
This resulted in this AEU player declaring that the Allied Pirates were a force
for good and ultimately become branded a traitor for their actions, while the
Voice of the AEU would end up actively defecting to the Allied Pirates thanks to
the first player's actions.  The rest of the AEU playerbase, as with the Slaver
situation, refused to condemn the actions of either player for a considerable
amount of time and attempted to ignore that the situation was taking place,
again until the AEU government (the staff) forced the issue.
The AEU government was very displeased and highly vocal about what it expected
from AEU pilots and the response to pirates, and made a point to indicate that
the AEU pilot corps was now treading on thin ice after so many prior missteps.
Renewed Hope
--
Seeing how much negativity had come from the AEU in recent times, the staff
decided that we needed to do something to allow the AEU to show some positivity
instead.  So - since the AEU players kept crying out that they wanted to explore
- we set up a government initiative known as the Explorer's Corps; a special
group that players could be invited into if they showed their exploration
expertise.
We had many good and fun things planned and hinted at several in-game, hoping to
inspire the AEU players - people who constantly said they wanted to explore - to
actually do so.
After several months, not a single AEU player had taken up the challenge.
The Krupin Report
--
A new AEU player.  Taken on an expedition led, once again, by someone not AEU. 
Tensions rise and - after an unusual event within the rift - explode.  The
player is sent home via escape pod and in revenge begins a campaign of character
assassination of the rest of the crew, who are still out in deep space, by
claiming that they are dangerous and have gone mad thanks to the rift.  Petty,
but potentially interesting.
The AEU players back in home space offer verbal support to their fellow AEUer,
but have little interest in actively doing anything to deal with a potentially
insane crew of skilled long-time pilots.  The options are that the AEU pilot is
lying or that a rift event has caused a crew of talented pilots to lose their
minds - there is no middle ground in this scenario, either the crew have gone
mad or they have not.  Yet the AEU playerbase said that they supported the AEU
player's statements, but that the crew going mad was 'probably not important'.
The AEU Voice at the time is tasked by the government to gather information to
determine how valid the claims are - and is told exactly how they can easily do
this (by using the Quantum Entanglement device linked to the expedition ship in
question).  They do not follow these guidelines, instead choosing to vaguely
agree with the claims made by the AEU pilot without offering specific details or
facts, and ultimately doing no research whatsoever into the claims.  When the
government informs the Voice that they require an active decision from them, the
Voice immediately takes the path of least resistance and buckles, calling the
player a liar - again after doing zero research into the matter.
Thus the player discusses their final plan - the extinction of ALL HUMANITY
through activating beacons in Mutuality space... to get revenge on a small crew
who sent them home to avoid infighting.  When this came out the AEU government
needed to act and immediately revoked the player's licence - but eventually
returned it after deciding that their ranting was hyperbole rather than insanity
or actual intent (an opinion shared by the AEU players), along with the fact
that she was unable to actively achieve said goal due to being banned from
Mutuality space.  The player ultimately ranted both ICly and OOCly about what
had happened and then deleted the character.
This was the final straw - after yet another outrageous situation, the AEU
government made good on its threats and stopped allowing cadets into the AEU
civilian pilot program.
--
Each of these mini-events, taken by themselves, is a problem but not
game-changing.  They could all have added to the game story and created useful
drama.  However, the consistency with which AEU players cause massively negative
story arcs to themselves and the AEU as a whole is impressive - and entirely
down to two problems that are not limited to AEU players, but are most extreme
with them:  inaction and doubling down.
The majority of players refuse to take a stand or make an active choice when
there is no 100% guarantee that they will benefit from doing so. Instead, they
will always take the path of least resistance and go with whatever decision is
easiest for them to make without having to do anything.
The few players who don't do this have a tendency to 'double down' - that is, to
continue to up the ante in whatever decision they have made until they reach
extreme levels, in the belief that once they've made a decision, it has to be
followed to the bitter end even if they know things will get worse; basically,
escalating a minor problem into a major one.
--
ELECTION FEVER
--
Our most recent attempt to give the AEU playerbase a chance to show us what they
wanted was something that had been planned for some time but never actually set
in motion - the first post-Resistance general election.  This, we thought, was a
chance to get some debate going about the future of the AEU!  What did the
players want?  What were they going to talk about?  What was going to be the
main focus?
The status quo and personal gain, apparently.  
The three 'main' candidates were fairly specific in their public policies.  
* Garner's focus was progress in the AEU as a whole and attempting to end its
isolation, but hardship for the pilot community.  
* Rebane's interests were in less government oversight, basically allowing the
pilots to remain as they were, but giving corporations a more powerful sphere of
influence within the main AEU and the civilian pilot corps.
* Best's choice was to continue the path laid out by the players - to remove its
vestigal interest in exploration, to continue its jingoistic obsession with
separating itself from the rest of the alliances while pushing for greater
glory.
We were not entirely surprised, though we were disappointed, to see almost the
entire AEU playerbase immediately latch on to Best's rhetoric without even a
token discussion.  Garner was bad and discounted because of his (fairly
reasonable) reaction to the constant and consistent problems that the AEU
civilian corps had caused.  Rebane was discounted as the middle road option. 
Best was supported because he promised toys and told people the AEU would be
great again.
Politics at its finest.
The election results themselves were always intended to be fairly even, with the
AEU playerbase vote OOCly swinging things one way or another.  Rebane was always
the outlier, with only a near-unanimous vote for her by the players likely to
elect her (OOCly, of course).  The real battle was of course Garner versus Best.
 
100% of the player vote went to Best.  So of course that pushed him to victory.
The AEU pilots chose jingoistic fascism.  Now they reap the rewards of what has
been sown.
--
CONCLUSION
--
Star Conquest is a roleplaying game, and the staff enjoy putting on events and
story arcs both large and small.  But we can only do so with player engagement -
and consistently negative outcomes is as hard for us as it is for the players.
We have been concerned about the direction the AEU has been taking for some
time, but if the ultimate choice of the playerbase is to have events transpire
where the AEU eventually reaches an untenable position, we will go that route.
However, if that is NOT the route that AEU players want to take, we cannot stop
that from happening without player help.  If you want positive things to happen,
you need to MAKE them happen.  If you want improvement to the AEU, be that
improvement.
There are no quick fixes to this.  This has been a situation four real life
years in the making.  Every time we have tried to set up a situation to make
things better for the AEU the response (or lack thereof) of the AEU playerbase
has made it so much worse, to the point where we actually worry about making
further attempts to give options to fix things because we fear the inevitable
result.
One consistent comment we have seen is the line that the AEU should develop
better exploration tech.  If you want better exploration technology, show it
will be used.  EXPLORE.  Lead expeditions.  Find new things.  Technology doesn't
improve because people ask for it, it improves because it's profitable to work
on it, because people use what they have already.
The League, the Mutuality, and the Fringe all get new toys related to what their
players DO, not what they SAY.  The same applies to the AEU.  If AEU players
actually explore, the AEU will develop more exploration tech.  If all you do is
SAY you want more toys, you will get absolutely nothing.  
If things continue as they have, the AEU will continue as it is and will
eventually either collapse in on itself or start a confrontation on multiple
fronts that can only end one way...
And if it does, it will be entirely your fault.
--

Subject: Re: DIATRIBE OF FURY: THE FALL OF THE AEU
Author: nadira
Posted: Fri Nov 25 21:55:37 2016 UTC
--
Hi,
I am not angry. Do I like this situation? No, I don't. But it is at least for 99
percent true.
There is one minor thing I do want to comment on today. Although my character's
exploration trip was not a policy 14, she still tried to organize some
exploration. i had my reasons for taking the trip this way, it was meant to be a
preparation for more exploration trips, some possibly might end up as policy 14
events. i just wanted to get my character to try and run something, learn how to
organize stuff, how to take responsibility for an entire crew, the things she
would need to be aware of and prepare. It wasn't just for my character a
learning experience, for me as a player as well. It is regretable that only 2
other AEU characters showed any sort of interest in joining that trip.
There is a lot more that I could say here, a lot more that I should say here
probably, but I will need some time to think certain things through.
to be continued.
--

--
Enter your selection:
Your ship 'Justen Moon' has been automatically moved into a garage.

Enter the body of your post.
[Type lines of input; use `.' to end or `@abort' to abort the command.]
Thank you for posting that. Although reading it may have stirred up some
frustrations and strong feelings, I know personally that I needed to read that.
It has given me much to think about. I do have one question though and I'm sure
I'll have more later. When referring to "exploration tech" and its lack of use,
are we talking specifically of just focusing on using AEU tech more? I know some
of us have or have looked into obtaining a tactical platform with attached
sightseers as a large exploration ship. However, this does not use any specific
AEU exploration ships.
*

Enter the body of your post.
[Type lines of input; use `.' to end or `@abort' to abort the command.]
Thank you for posting that. Although reading it may have stirred up some
frustrations and strong feelings, I know personally that I needed to read that.
It has given me much to think about. I do have one question though and I'm sure
I'll have more later. When referring to "exploration tech" and its lack of use,
are we talking specifically of just focusing on using AEU tech more? I know some
of us have or have looked into obtaining a tactical platform with attached
sightseers as a large exploration ship. However, this does not use any specific
AEU exploration ships.
*
.
--
Subject: Re: DIATRIBE OF FURY: THE FALL OF THE AEU
--
Thank you for posting that. Although reading it may have stirred up some
frustrations and strong feelings, I know personally that I needed to read that.
It has given me much to think about. I do have one question though and I'm sure
I'll have more later. When referring to "exploration tech" and its lack of use,
are we talking specifically of just focusing on using AEU tech more? I know some
of us have or have looked into obtaining a tactical platform with attached
sightseers as a large exploration ship. However, this does not use any specific
AEU exploration ships.
--

y
You feel the ship shudder slightly as it approaches a quantum skim accelerator.
The computer announces, "Initiating connection with Gateway's local quantum skim
accelerator network."
The computer announces, "Connection established. Communicating between quantum
skim acceleration gates now."
The computer announces, "Skim subroutine initializing in five seconds."
The computer announces, "Four."
The computer announces, "Three."
The computer announces, "Two."
The computer announces, "One."
The computer announces, "Skim subroutine initialized."
You feel the deck underneath you shudder violently, and you stumble slightly.
The shuddering finally settles down.
The computer announces, "Skim initialization complete."
[AEU | 10: Conquest Status] An AEU pilot corps liaison transmits, "$e're getting
-}ose to@th)t first#.erform]n*e go)l! Let's go!"
The computer announces, "Skim complete; starship has arrived at journey
destination."
ftl new
Providence Station shines brightly in the dark, one of the few stations that
bothers to illuminate its outer hull. The gleaming hull of the station is bathed
with bright white floodlights.
New Earth rotates through space before you, a startingly verdant planet, colored
in greens and blues with pure white clouds.
Via general sector communication, New Earth transmits, "Hello there, Justen
Moon! Welcome to home space!"

You see a sleek metal quantum entanglement communication device, a rattan floor
lamp with a light purple lotus shade (casting a white-colored glow), a wormhole
drive tracer, a dark purple leather captain's chair, a large oval white and
black cloth rug, a rare black EAOSian contoured couch with a hand-made white and
sapphire star quilt on it, a round white rattan coffee table with a glass top, a
small yellow ball containing a realistic Bari horde noisemaker, a glossy gold
ceramic felo chow bowl, a wall-sized bubbling neon purple-lit aquarium
containing yellow and red aquatic life and coral rocks, a small white trash bin,
a compact red refrigerator, a clear plastic food storage container, a blue
plastic food storage container, Magellan the arachnoid security robot, a compact
white refrigerator, and Purr the humanoid service robot here.

read book
A Tardick lizard named Asteria curls its tail loosely around Lily Kaise's neck.
An AEU Pilot's Guide To Ships And Upgrades                                      
  Page 18
Long-term rentals:
The fighter and heavy bomber listed in this section are generally similar to the
ones rented at Tannhauser, save for the fact that I'm pretty sure they start out
with stock upgrades and have to be upgraded by the long-term renter. The modular
tactical platform and the Modular Terrorerotici both can only have
corporation-based fighters such as the hyperion ships or the ones rented either
short-term or long-term by Agnar attached to them as far as we've deduced, as
well as the shuttles manufactured by corporations such as Hermes or United. You
can attach the ships to the platforms only from space. Note: the docking bay
size of the tactical platform and the Terrorerotici will increase depending on
the types of ships you have attached to them.
One-Person A.S.S. Fighter 2,000,000.00 (Helios Agnarr's Interstellar Siege Force
Long Term Rental)
ASS-A1 ALLIED STARSHIPS SPACE SUPERIORITY FIGHTER
Requirements: 0 industry points
Model number: ASS-A1                    Designation: A.S.S. Fighter
Turret hardpoints: 4                    Launcher hardpoints: 1
Standard storage capacity: 6500         Standard battery hours: 3
Docking bay size required: 5
Class Modifications:
Damage vs. Small Ships: 120%            Hull Hit Chance by Small Ships: 90%
Instantaneous Speed: 105%
One-Person A.S.S. Bomber 15,000,000.00 (Helios Agnarr's Interstellar Siege Force
Long Term Rental)
ASS-A2 ALLIED STARSHIPS HEAVY BOMBER
Requirements: 200 industry points       200 combat points
Model number: ASS-A2                    Designation: A.S.S. Bomber
Turret hardpoints: 2                    Launcher hardpoints: 2
Standard storage capacity: 9750         Standard battery hours: 6
Docking bay size required: 5
Class Modifications:
Damage vs. Small Ships: 120%            Hull Hit Chance by Small Ships: 90%
Instantaneous Speed: 105%
Three-Person A.S.S. Modular Terrorerotici 250,000,000.00 (Helios Agnarr's
Interstellar Siege Force Long Term Rental)
ASS-C4 ALLIED STARSHIPS BUDGET-CONSTRAINED MODULAR TERROREROTICISM VESSEL
Requirements: 750 industry points       750 combat points
Model number: ASS-C4                    Designation: A.S.S. Modular
Terroreroticist
Turret hardpoints: 0                    Launcher hardpoints: 0
Standard storage capacity: 10000        Standard battery hours: 6
Docking bay size required: 35
Class Modifications:
Damage vs. Small Ships: 105%            Hull Hit Chance by Small Ships: 95%
Max Cruising Speed: 102%
ASS-E7 ALLIED STARSHIPS MODULAR TACTICAL PLATFORM
Requirements: 1250 industry points      1250 combat points
Model number: ASS-E7                    Designation: A.S.S. Tactical Platform
Turret hardpoints: 0                    Launcher hardpoints: 0
Standard storage capacity: 20000        Standard battery hours: 2
Docking bay size required: 50
Class Modifications:
Instantaneous Speed: 95%
Six-Person A.S.S. Frigate (approval required) (Helios Agnarr's Interstellar
Siege Force Long Term Rental)
ASS-F1 ALLIED STARSHIPS DEFENSE FRIGATE
Requirements: 1000 industry points      1000 combat points
Model number: ASS-F1                    Designation: A.S.S. Frigate
Turret hardpoints: 12                   Launcher hardpoints: 4
Standard storage capacity: 32000        Standard battery hours: 8
Docking bay size required: 100          Docking bay capacity: 37.5
   Class Modifications:
Instantaneous Speed: 95%
If you want to own a six-person ship to do stuff in and don't quite qualify for
the Pincer, then this ship is for you! It has fewer weapons, but would be able
to perform well enough in a fight with decent upgrades. It does however require
you to fill out an application, and approval or denial notifications may take
some time to reach you, but you'll be notified by mail regardless.
A large thickly-shelled creature with a yellow shell and four small claws snaps
its claws menacingly at a plastic flower with red petals.
read book
An AEU Pilot's Guide To Ships And Upgrades                                      
  Page 18
Long-term rentals:
The fighter and heavy bomber listed in this section are generally similar to the
ones rented at Tannhauser, save for the fact that I'm pretty sure they start out
with stock upgrades and have to be upgraded by the long-term renter. The modular
tactical platform and the Modular Terrorerotici both can only have
corporation-based fighters such as the hyperion ships or the ones rented either
short-term or long-term by Agnar attached to them as far as we've deduced, as
well as the shuttles manufactured by corporations such as Hermes or United. You
can attach the ships to the platforms only from space. Note: the docking bay
size of the tactical platform and the Terrorerotici will increase depending on
the types of ships you have attached to them.

Six-Person A.S.S. Frigate (approval required) (Helios Agnarr's Interstellar
Siege Force Long Term Rental)
ASS-F1 ALLIED STARSHIPS DEFENSE FRIGATE
Requirements: 1000 industry points      1000 combat points
Model number: ASS-F1                    Designation: A.S.S. Frigate
Turret hardpoints: 12                   Launcher hardpoints: 4
Standard storage capacity: 32000        Standard battery hours: 8
Docking bay size required: 100          Docking bay capacity: 37.5
   Class Modifications:
Instantaneous Speed: 95%
If you want to own a six-person ship to do stuff in and don't quite qualify for
the Pincer, then this ship is for you! It has fewer weapons, but would be able
to perform well enough in a fight with decent upgrades. It does however require
you to fill out an application, and approval or denial notifications may take
some time to reach you, but you'll be notified by mail regardless.

help geography
--
Star Conquest Help: Space Geography
--
Category: Game Systems
--
Star Conquest has a fully-realized space system as one of its primary features.
Space is big and it can be confusing. Sometimes intentionally! But here are the
basics.
SECTORS
Space is divided into sectors, which are simply a way of marking off and
differentiating volumes of space.
Sectors are three-dimensional, and are further subdivided into coordinates: 20
by 20 by 20.
Numbers! Each sector is 240,000km across on each axis, or about 1/625th of an
astronomical unit, or about 8/10ths of a light-second. So, a lightyear is just
shy of 40 million sectors. This would be common knowledge among pilots.
BEACONS
A sector exists because a beacon has been placed there broadcasting its
location. This beacon is what allows starships to jump there using their
wormhole drive.
Beacons can be based on planets, on space stations, or free-floating in a beacon
housing.
There are three types of beacons you'll commonly encounter:
* Primary beacons: These are beacons for main sectors that you can jump to from
any location (with a few exceptions). Examples are Earthgate, Providence Gate,
or the Dusty Reaches. These are primary thoroughfares and also act as travel
bottlenecks.
* Secondary beacons: These are used within a sector cluster. For instance, Old
Earth Orbit and Martian Orbit are both marked by secondary beacons. What this
means is that from another sector cluster, you would first have to jump to
Earthgate, because that is the primary beacon for the cluster. From there, you
can jump to Old Earth or Mars, the secondary beacons.
* Weak beacons: These are not really a separate category, because primary or
secondary beacons can also be weak. Weak beacons do not broadcast over a wide
range, and generally a ship's computer must know of its approximate location
before it can scan for a weak beacon. Scanning will still usually take several
attempts. Weak beacons are used in Mutuality space to help it remain hidden.
SECURITY
Sectors also each have a security rating describing the degree of safety you can
expect there. Check the SECURITY RATINGS help file for more information.
MOVING BETWEEN SECTORS
You can travel to other sectors with your starship's JUMP command. You can type
this command by itself for a list of accessible sectors, or you can type JUMP
[sector name] to start traveling there immediately. For instance, JUMP EARTHGATE
will take you straight to the Earthgate sector from most locations.
Your starship can also successfully navigate multiple jumps. For instance, if
you're in a distant sector cluster and you type JUMP OLD EARTH, your ship will
automatically travel first to Earthgate and then make a second jump to Old Earth
Orbit. Linked jumps such as these will occur faster and use less battery charge
than if you performed the jumps individually.
--

Subject: Re: DIATRIBE OF FURY: THE FALL OF THE AEU
Author: atherj
Posted: Fri Nov 25 22:35:22 2016 UTC
--
I'm going to try to cover as many of your points as I can in this post. However,
they will not be in order, so I will offer quotes from your posts and my
explanations of why I put in those quotes.
"As expected, the Mutuality was the outlier - originally (after an initial
stumbling block) the Mutuality had had relatively strong ties to the AEU and
Fringe. However, as time went on events both staff and player initiated caused
tension between the Mutuality and both AEU and Fringe, leaving lasting scars and
giving the League a chance to swoop in and forge closer ties to the Mutuality."
I don't know where that particular thing is coming from. In my experiences (and
I was around since pretty much the opening events) the Mutuality never had
strong ties with the AEU. Especially after the whole AEU rogue navy disaster
which was not player-initiated. That was all followed closely by the weapon
platform incidents around gateway, where we also shot down a Mutuality sponsored
pilot's vessel in an AEU ship, though that could be one of the staff-initiated
event arcs that you were referring to in your post.
"And then the AEU pilot corps unilaterally decided to break diplomatic ties with
all the other alliances, remaining neutral to them all."
A vote was taken on that proposal, and agreed on by the majority of the active
pilots. So, I don't see why this was a surprise. Being the person who initiated
this (it's alright, I'll call myself out) I wanted to see what would happen if
the alliance stood alone, without piggybacking on other alliances for help other
than free trade and the like. I don't know what's wrong with that, and I still
don't see anything wrong with that. We weren't rewarded for that initiative
though, probably because of the other things that I will be covering further
down. Keep reading!
I'm not going to cover the slaver issue in great detail. I've already written
several things about the entire thing in other message board threads, and made
my displeasure about how the whole thing was handled both OOCly and ICly quite
clearly. If people want additional information, I'll jot down my thoughts.
"A while after this, the Voice at the time was convinced to attempt to
re-establish diplomatic relations with the Mutuality."
Again, I don't mind calling myself out. Yep, totally me again. All happened as
was said. Pretty much in the entire paragraph. With further elaboration as
stated previously in-character basically covering it: why bother bowing and
scraping to them when they want us to move mountains that are unmoveable?
"After getting lost in deep space, another new AEU player and friend of the
Voice was rescued by Mister Kelsey - as he is wont to do now and then for
reasons of his own."
Please give me another example of this instance ever occuring again? I've never
heard about this kind of thing happening except for that one particular instance
unless we're counting invasions for some inexplicable reason. Granted, the
events that transpired were entirely the fault of the people involved.
Otherwise, let us press on, shall we?
"The rest of the AEU playerbase, as with the Slaver situation, refused to
condemn the actions of either player for a considerable amount of time and
attempted to ignore that the situation was taking place, again until the AEU
government (the staff) forced the issue."
I don't know where that's coming from, as I pretty much condemned their actions
from day one, and when I had discussions with the voice behind closed doors,
told them that Mr. Kelsey should not be trusted. I didn't hear any other AEU
pilots defending them either at the time, though I also do not recall any other
remarks of public condemnation.
"Seeing how much negativity had come from the AEU in recent times, the staff
decided that we needed to do something to allow the AEU to show some positivity
instead. So - since the AEU players kept crying out that they wanted to explore
- we set up a government initiative known as the Explorer's Corps
a special group that players could be invited into if they showed their
exploration expertise."
Lovely idea. From an OOC perspective though, I've honestly been idle more than
active for the last several months. I've had a lot of stuff on my plate, been
hanging out more with friends, spending more time with family etc. That's about
as OOCly detailed as I'd like to get about my life on a public forum in a game
where I'd rather not establish a deep relationship with other players on an OOC
basis. Anyway, that's the big thing that's always kept me from leading
expeditions.
I don't have any particular quotes from the election that I want to use, so i'll
just try to cover it in detail here. Garner: my player didn't want him because
he still believes, perhaps naively that the AEU can stand alone and with a bit
of hard work, accomplish what they want to accomplish, doing it better than
everyone else because they had to work so hard for it. Rebane: sounded a bit too
passive for me, honestly. Best: let's make the AEU great again! Something that
resonated with my player's beliefs, even if he didn't agree with all of Best's
ideas on how to make the AEU great again. However, he spoke to my player's
personal beliefs about how the AEU can stand alone, and still be a great
alliance. Unfortunately, I believe too much OOC has been taken from this
situation. Perhaps a bit by the players, and a bit by the staff as well. A lot
of what has been happening in the AEU election, and the real-life presidential
election in the United States has been remarkably similar. That's been obvious
for several months, but not pointed out by a lot of people that I've seen. Which
honestly, is a bit disheartening to the OOC me. I go to this game to get away
from real-life election stuff and all the political crap that goes with it. If I
want to read about it, all I have to do is look at my twitter timeline. Now
though, I get to see it ingame too, which is...just eh, in my opinion.
At this point and time, I honestly don't know where I want the AEU to go. We've
had a lot happen in recent years where it feels like certain players
intentionally wanted to sabotage the alliance for some reason or other (no, I
don't believe that remaining at non-aggression pact levels is actually sabotage
before anyone tries to point fingers at my player). Anyway, it just feels like
all possible avenues at redemption have been closed off. Some of it is player
fault, but some of it is definitely staff fault too. There have been things that
have been done and said which were then taken to extreme levels by staff-driven
roleplay. I will only grant that yes, often times, the staff-driven roleplay was
a result of a player's action. However, I will still say that some of it has
been extreme. I will provide examples if you'd like.
That's all for now though. Flame away.
--

Subject: Re: DIATRIBE OF FURY: THE FALL OF THE AEU
Author: nadira
Posted: Fri Nov 25 23:44:22 2016 UTC
--
Upon reading what Atherj posted, and digesting a few things from the original
post, there are some things I will try to comment on.
Tatiana. The first thought my character had when Syona and Tatiana arrived back
home was, oh god, what did they do. It was the first time crew members were sent
home from a trip. I had not been playing for personal reasons for a while, so my
character did not know either one of these people. But she knew Nissi as a
decent and balanced person, Anfisa as a skilled person, maybe with a temper but
not entirely without reason. The exact accusation Tatiana made was unknown to my
character until the message on the qe from metal heart arrived. You say there is
no in the middle but I don't agree with you there. My character trusted the
people on that ship to make the right decisions, generally. It was not
unreasonable to expect that Tatiana and Syona were overwhelmed with what
happened during a trip, these trips are not for everyone. It is also not
entirely known what rift entities can do. Did they offend someone, was it the
pressure from all being stuck in a ship? Or was something really wrong with the
crew. So, Tatiana and Syona could have overreacted, or they could have said
something that may have offended someone,without talking with everyone, it was
not easy to learn. So I had my character investigate, talk with Tatiana because
Syona was unavailable. As the conversation continued, it became clear from some
of the things Tatiana said to my character, that, pardon the expression, she had
a screw loose. But without the crew home to actually talk to them, it was still
not easy to figure out what exactly happened. The thought that Tatiana was just
overwhelmed by events during the trip lost merrit though, and the news story on
the holovid took any remaining doubt my character had away, Tatiana must have
done something to upset or annoy this crew, the way she talked to my character,
and then the mentions of revenge, quarentine being the next best thing. Before
that point, my character gave Tatiana the benifit of the doubt, then the benifit
of the doubt was gone, and that is how I roleplayed the story from then on,
including having my character propose she'd be removed from office. This only
after several more attempts of getting her to admit to the truth. Talking with
Tatiana had become increasingly impossible, simply because from the way she
talked, you just never could be sure whether she meant it. And what the secret
plan was? The only people who finally got Tatiana to the point of telling them,
never told any of us, so when the government learned, that was also the first my
character heard about the plan to launch beacons in mutuality space using a
league ship. And I can not remember that my character ever said things that
suggested she did not take what Tatiana was threatening seriously. I remember a
very frustrated conversation in which several of us tried to get Tatiana to see
how wrong she was, how terrible it was what she threatened. That it was no joke,
and it all glanced off her like it didn't matter. And a week later she had her
license back, after which she deleted her character. And I remember thinking,
what the....
As for the incident with Jonathan and Annie, where she stated that Jonathan had
ran from his responsibility and redirected the rescue pod on purpose... Maybe we
didn't throw her out of office for it when we should have done that, but stating
that none of us ever reacted, that no one ever got angry with her, is also not
true. I remember a very overheated conversation in the office, and after Annie
failed to blame it on Jonathan, she tried to throw my character under the bus.
She, oh I might as well just use her name here, Kim, upon learning that Jonathan
had redirected the rescue pod to Helios and what danger was about to arise from
that, said that we should talk to Jonathan and have a general discussion about
how we were going to fix this. A week later, she claimed that Kim had wanted her
to file a report with the liaison office that Jonathan had ran away with the
intention to escape. This was never said, and there were some very angry words
about it.
Don't get me wrong, I am not pretending I didn't make mistakes, that things I
did, or didn't do haven't added to this situation. The slave trades are the
worst example of what inaction can lead to, and as a player I sure have done a
lot of nothing in that department. And even in the past 2 years there are a
number of incidents where my character got upset, but maybe did not do all the
things she could have done to work towards a change.
I unfortunately so have to agree with Atherj on the comparison between real life
and SC presidents. That part was really not evident to me, I did not consider
it, until this violence thing got thrown in the mix.
No, I don't want to see the AEU continue down hill like this. It is a very sad
thing and honestly started long before I ever knew about the existance of Star
Conquest, and involves characters and players who are not in the picture
anymore. I see where Gordon and the other hosts are coming from, I also see a
few things where atherj may have a point. I am honestly not sure where to begin
fixing this, but I will sleep on it.
Have a nice evening everyone.
--

[2] Return
[3] Reply
[4] Quit

l lift
a space lifter (attached to a basic control center module (contributed by
Risoluto E Unisono Noblezza Espressione))
This appears to be similar to a hovering pallet frontloader frequently seen
around spaceports. This model, according to several symbols etched into its
side, is rated for vacuum and zero gravity.

out
[Outside Segue]
You see a space lifter (attached to a basic control center module) here.
You can go in any direction using a spacejet, or return to Segue.
You are weightless here.
You step out of the open bay door, and drift into space as the ship's artificial
gravity releases you.

l
[Accord of Free Worlds; Service Ring]
A large transparisteel window is on the station's port side here, as tall as
both main rings together. The transparisteel is slightly darkened, both
polarized and reinforced with some other material, perhaps even trace
neutronium. The bulkheads and deck are made of a darkened, glossy metal, though
not as dark as the station's exterior. Emergency lights are mounted every three
meters overhead. Light blue trim where the bulkheads meet the deck indicate that
this is the Service Deck.
You can go north, east, and south.

[Starship "Herding Cats"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. Lights
overhead indicate that the ship is on green status. Looking through the windows,
you see that the ship is in space.
You see a large white and strawberry red paisley floor pillow with thick silver
fringe and a comfy neon purple Business Cats floor pillow here.
You can go south and out.
move
The starship is already moving.

wait.

[1] The Shoulder of Orion (Unclaimed)
[2] The Belt of Orion (Unclaimed)
Enter your selection:
2
A pair of odd-colored stars, one green and one blue, mark this curious area of
space. The sensors are picking up odd bits of noise that the ship's computer
insists on trying to convert to audio. Once in a while, something that could
almost sound like a word emerges from a burst of static.
The computer reports that in-sector beacons are transmitting the following:
S*s30G'Y`z&$Xm&^An|PZ~@.X8%wix~8ge]_5TZi
This area of space is within the green belt of the nearest star, but there are
no life-bearing planets here. Instead there is merely an odd cluster of space
stations of unknown origin.
The sensor noise is much worse here, with a constant dark, gutteral snarling
sound emanating from the ship's speakers. It almost sounds like a language, but
it's nothing you've ever heard before, and the ship's computer cannot pinpoint a
source.
Via general sector communication, a temporary space station transmits, "Hello
pilots, welcome to Belt of Orion. Remember to watch your ship's charge, have
enough EAOS credits for tolls, and most importantly, fly safe!"
Via general sector communication, Beacon E-02 transmits in a robotic voice,
"Detecting vessel 'Herding Cats.' Welcome to The Belt of Orion."
ftl 285
This rift accelerator requires paying a toll of 7,000,000.00 EAOS credits. Do
you wish to pay this?
[Enter `yes' or `no']
y
You transfer a toll payment to a local rift accelerator.
The computer announces, "Setting course to Asteroid Beacon Alpha 285. Local rift
accelerator with matching vector found."
Something deep inside the starship roars to life as the lights dim sharply.
A wormhole suddenly appears in front of the ship, its edges tinged an unusual
deep purple. Strange undulating shapes are half-visible deep inside it.
A thick undulating mist suddenly seems to rush toward the starship from every
direction, quickly blotting out the stars. Random shapes, some half-familiar,
occasionally form in the mist only to disappear almost immediately.
The computer beeps in an imperative manner and informs you that the starship's
sensors have detected a new location of interest in the riftflow.
The computer beeps in an imperative manner and informs you that the starship's
sensors have detected a new location of interest in the riftflow.
The computer beeps in an imperative manner and informs you that the starship's
sensors have detected a new location of interest in the riftflow.
Bursts of multicolored light suddenly blind you as they slice across your view,
forming winding pathways through billowing clouds.
The computer beeps in an imperative manner and informs you that the starship's
sensors have detected a new location of interest in the riftflow.

salvage processor. Often you will also find a repair and recharge station here.

ftl home
The computer announces, "Setting course to Home Beacon Alpha 286. Local rift
accelerator with matching vector found."
Something deep inside the starship roars to life as the lights dim sharply.
[General Communication] Emmett Lee transmits, "Thanks Shule."
A wormhole suddenly appears in front of the ship, its edges tinged an unusual
deep purple. Strange undulating shapes are half-visible deep inside it.
A thick undulating mist suddenly seems to rush toward the starship from every
direction, quickly blotting out the stars. Random shapes, some half-familiar,
occasionally form in the mist only to disappear almost immediately.
The starship has left a unique area of space.
The computer beeps in an imperative manner and informs you that the starship's
sensors have detected a new location of interest in the riftflow.
A high pitched whistling sound screams overhead as a mortar shell flies through
the air. It explodes nearby with tremendous force, and when the dust and smoke
clears, the starship is gone, replaced with a deep earthen trench and the sounds
of battle.

ftl accord
A handful of lonely beacons watch over this area of space, their lights glowing
palely in the dark, surrounded by tendrils of drifting dust and debris.
A planet once existed here, until it was destroyed by the Outsiders. Now only
large chunks of the planet remain, still drifting slowly away from each other,
with clouds of debris filling the sector.
move
The starship is already moving.
A circular space station dominates this sector, made of darkened metal
reinforced against attack. By the look of it, this is probably the most heavily
armored station in human space, excepting The Torus. This is the heart of the
Accord of Free Worlds.

l
[Starship "Segue"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. The
status lights overhead are currently not receiving power. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is at Accord of Free Worlds Command; Docking Bay
Four.
You see a large leather chair, a large leather couch, a holovid, a gold trophy
in the shape of an ancient well, a blue plastic paper dispenser, a sheet of
orange paper, a sheet of red paper, a sheet of red paper, a sheet of green
paper, a sheet of white paper, a sheet of white paper, a sheet of orange paper,
a sheet of white paper, a sheet of orange paper, a projector, a sheet of green
paper, a sheet of orange paper, a sheet of green paper, a sheet of white paper,
a sheet of white paper, a sheet of yellow paper, and a sheet of orange paper
here.

[Starship "Shooting Star"; Control Capsule]
This small capsule is only large enough for one person. A single flight seat
molds itself to the form of its occupant, helping to ease the burden of
acceleration along with a rather underpowered artificial gravity dampening
system. The capsule's inner workings extend into the flight cabin, with the
starship's main computer right up against the back of the seat. A rather sparse
flight control board is presented claustrophobically close to the pilot's face.
It seems to lack any sort of manual control, allowing only automatic flight
profiles to be entered into an antiquated flight computer. It does, however,
possess controls to operate a single small turret. Lights overhead indicate that
the ship is on green status. Looking through the windows, you see that the ship
is in space. The hatch appears to be locked.
You see an improved temporary wormhole drive here.
You can go nowhere.
(You are sitting.)
Providence Station shines brightly in the dark, one of the few stations that
bothers to illuminate its outer hull. The gleaming hull of the station is bathed
with bright white floodlights.
sit
You're already sitting.
New Earth rotates through space before you, a startingly verdant planet, colored
in greens and blues with pure white clouds.
Via general sector communication, New Earth transmits, "Hello there, Shooting
Star! Welcome to home space!"
move

wait.

y
You notify flight control of your desire to land.
A voice comes over the speaker and says, "Hello, Shooting Star. We read your AEU
transponder. You are cleared to land at the city of New Phoenix."
power
You pull a large lever towards you.
The faint sounds and status lights of the starship's systems slowly fade away,
leaving you in a dim silence.
out
You scramble to your feet.
You exit the capsule.

slowly moved into a large garage.

[Starship "William Dove"; Control Room]
You see a sleek metal quantum entanglement communication device, a rattan floor
lamp with a light purple lotus shade (casting a white-colored glow), a wormhole
drive tracer, a dark purple leather captain's chair, a large oval white and
black cloth rug, a rare black EAOSian contoured couch with a hand-made white and
sapphire star quilt on it, a round white rattan coffee table with a glass top, a
small yellow ball containing a realistic Bari horde noisemaker, a glossy gold
ceramic felo chow bowl, a wall-sized bubbling neon purple-lit aquarium
containing yellow and red aquatic life and coral rocks, a small white trash bin,
a compact red refrigerator, a clear plastic food storage container, a blue
plastic food storage container, Magellan the arachnoid security robot, a compact
white refrigerator, and Purr the humanoid service robot here.
Lily Kaise is dozing on a rare black EAOSian contoured couch.
You can go south and out.
l
[Starship "William Dove"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. The
status lights overhead are currently not receiving power. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is at New Earth; Spaceport Landing Pad.
You see a sleek metal quantum entanglement communication device, a rattan floor
lamp with a light purple lotus shade (casting a white-colored glow), a wormhole
drive tracer, a dark purple leather captain's chair, a large oval white and
black cloth rug, a rare black EAOSian contoured couch with a hand-made white and
sapphire star quilt on it, a round white rattan coffee table with a glass top, a
small yellow ball containing a realistic Bari horde noisemaker, a glossy gold
ceramic felo chow bowl, a wall-sized bubbling neon purple-lit aquarium
containing yellow and red aquatic life and coral rocks, a small white trash bin,
a compact red refrigerator, a clear plastic food storage container, a blue
plastic food storage container, Magellan the arachnoid security robot, a compact
white refrigerator, and Purr the humanoid service robot here.
Lily Kaise is dozing on a rare black EAOSian contoured couch.
You can go south and out.
l lily
Lily Kaise
She appears to be 27 years old. She is about five feet and two inches tall and
has fair skin. Her body is thin with attractively curved hips and shapely
calves. She has slender shoulders and slightly larger than average breasts. Her
abdomen is attractive and punctuated by a cute navel. Her face is oval and
pretty, with a delicate nose and understated chin. Her lips are lovely and blush
pink and occasionally part to reveal a set of pretty teeth. Beneath a set of
arched eyebrows, her eyes are blue-green and almond-shaped. Her waist-length,
straight hair is pale honey blonde and swept up into a thick fall of loose curls
down her back. She has oval pink fingernails.
A small enameled crimson dragon pierces her belly button, a small enameled
cerulean blue dragonfly pierces her left earlobe, and a small enameled cerulean
blue dragonfly pierces her right earlobe.
 She is wearing a short red cotton tee with a large lacy heart printed on the
front, a pair of blue low rise denim jeans, and a pair of tan suede clogs. She
is also wearing an orange and white blessed prayer bracelet around her wrist, a
slender bracelet of tiny tinkling silver bells around her wrist, a neon purple
wrist-mounted chronometer, a solid silver ring engraved with dragonflies, a
delicate ring of silver wire and small purple amethyst crystals, a light purple
flightbag with a pastel kitten on the side, a soft fuchsia Tardick lizard
snuggly labeled 'Asteria', a metallic gold touch einrophone in a metallic purple
reinforced plastic phone holster, and a Tardick lizard named Asteria perched on
her shoulder. Her head, face, both eyes, neck, both elbows, abdomen, both
forearms, both wrists, both hands, and waist are left uncovered.
She is carrying nothing.
l tee on lily
a short red cotton tee with a large lacy heart printed on the front
This red cotton tee has short sleeves and a moderately scooped neck. Centered on
the front is a large lacy heart, and at the hem, which lies at mid-abdomen, is a
tiny tag embroidered with 'Bellies.'
It covers both your shoulders, both biceps, chest, and back.

[Starship "Starlight Express"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. The
status lights overhead are currently not receiving power. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is at New Earth; Spaceport Landing Pad.
You see a felo nest, a glossy pearl gray ceramic felo chow bowl, Mekensie the
humanoid service robot, a sleeping big violet soldier felo, and a big violet
bobtailed felo here.
You can go south and out.

The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large

back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. The
status lights overhead are currently not receiving power. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is at New Earth; Spaceport Landing Pad.
You see a felo nest, a glossy pearl gray ceramic felo chow bowl, a sleeping big
violet soldier felo, a big violet bobtailed felo, a hefty violet soldier felo
kitten, a big violet soldier felo kitten, and Mekensie the humanoid service
robot here.
You can go south and out.
l big violet
a sleeping big violet soldier felo
This strange, six-legged creature is vaguely wolf-like, though its head appears
almost vulpine. It is large in size and covered in short, striped violet fur,
possessing a short, thin tail that slowly flicks back and forth. The felo's
average-length, thick legs each end in three-toed paws with thick, curved white
claws, visible only when not retracted. A white, Bari nose sits below a pair of
clear blue eyes with vertical pupils. It appears to be sleeping.
l second big violet
a big violet bobtailed felo
This strange, six-legged creature is vaguely cat-like, though its head appears
almost vulpine. It is large in size and covered in short, striped violet fur.
Its tail is nothing but a short furry bump that wiggles around occasionally. The
felo's average-length, thick legs each end in three-toed paws with thick,
straight white claws visible. A white, heart nose sits below a pair of clear
blue eyes with vertical pupils.
l third big violet

ship is at New Earth; Spaceport Landing Pad. The hatch appears to be locked. A
small light near the hatch is dark and unpowered.

[Starship "William Dove"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. The
status lights overhead are currently not receiving power. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is at New Earth; Spaceport Landing Pad.
You see a sleek metal quantum entanglement communication device, a rattan floor
lamp with a light purple lotus shade (casting a white-colored glow), a wormhole
drive tracer, a dark purple leather captain's chair, a large oval white and
black cloth rug, a rare black EAOSian contoured couch with a hand-made white and
sapphire star quilt on it, a round white rattan coffee table with a glass top, a
small yellow ball containing a realistic Bari horde noisemaker, a glossy gold
ceramic felo chow bowl, a wall-sized bubbling neon purple-lit aquarium
containing yellow and red aquatic life and coral rocks, a small white trash bin,
a compact red refrigerator, a clear plastic food storage container, a blue
plastic food storage container, Magellan the arachnoid security robot, a compact
white refrigerator, Purr the humanoid service robot, and Blueberry the hefty
violet feathered felo here.
Lily Kaise is dozing on a rare black EAOSian contoured couch.
You can go south and out.
(You are sitting on a rare black EAOSian contoured couch with a hand-made white
and sapphire star quilt on it.)
Blueberry the hefty violet feathered felo wanders south.
l lily
Lily Kaise
She appears to be 27 years old. She is about five feet and two inches tall and
has fair skin. Her body is thin with attractively curved hips and shapely
calves. She has slender shoulders and slightly larger than average breasts. Her
abdomen is attractive and punctuated by a cute navel. Her face is oval and
pretty, with a delicate nose and understated chin. Her lips are lovely and blush
pink and occasionally part to reveal a set of pretty teeth. Beneath a set of
arched eyebrows, her eyes are blue-green and almond-shaped. Her waist-length,
straight hair is pale honey blonde and swept up into a thick fall of loose curls
down her back. She has oval pink fingernails.
A small enameled crimson dragon pierces her belly button, a small enameled
cerulean blue dragonfly pierces her left earlobe, and a small enameled cerulean
blue dragonfly pierces her right earlobe.
 She is wearing a short red cotton tee with a large lacy heart printed on the
front, a pair of blue low rise denim jeans, and a pair of tan suede clogs. She
is also wearing an orange and white blessed prayer bracelet around her wrist, a
slender bracelet of tiny tinkling silver bells around her wrist, a neon purple
wrist-mounted chronometer, a solid silver ring engraved with dragonflies, a
delicate ring of silver wire and small purple amethyst crystals, a light purple
flightbag with a pastel kitten on the side, a soft fuchsia Tardick lizard
snuggly labeled 'Asteria', a metallic gold touch einrophone in a metallic purple
reinforced plastic phone holster, and a Tardick lizard named Asteria perched on
her shoulder. Her head, face, both eyes, neck, both elbows, abdomen, both
forearms, both wrists, both hands, and waist are left uncovered.
She is carrying Jewel the large violet glowing felo in her right hand.

large chunks of the planet remain, still drifting slowly away from each other,
with clouds of debris filling the sector.

Enter your selection:
A circular space station dominates this sector, made of darkened metal
reinforced against attack. By the look of it, this is probably the most heavily
armored station in human space, excepting The Torus. This is the heart of the
Accord of Free Worlds.
Lily Kaise says in a New Earth accent, "Accelerator."
Via general sector communication, Accord of Free Worlds Command transmits,
"Hello, William Dove. Welcome to Accord space."
Lily Kaise presses a button and brings up the starship's navigation controls.
A destination appears on the ship's navigation controls: AFW Command (Dock
Four).
You notice Lily Kaise using the radio to ask for docking clearance.
A voice says over the speaker, "Roger, cleared to land at this Accord of Free
Worlds port."
'What's her transport called?
Invalid selection.
'What's her transport called?
You ask, "What's her transport called?"
Lily Kaise says in a New Earth accent, "Construction zone."
Lily Kaise pulls a large lever towards her.
The faint sounds and status lights of the starship's systems slowly fade away,
leaving you in a dim silence.
stand
Lily Kaise scrambles to her feet.
Lily Kaise glides out.
You stand up from a rare black EAOSian contoured couch with a hand-made white
and sapphire star quilt on it.

[Accord of Free Worlds Command; Docking Bay Four]
This is a fully modern docking bay, made of the same sleek, slightly darkened
metal that the exterior of the station is made from. Brightly painted yellow
lines mark entry and exit paths for ships, and rows of dotted lines indicate
where ships may touch down. A series of electromagnetic manipulators prevent
atmosphere from escaping into space when the bay door is opened. One of the EMMs
is emitting a steady hum, indicating that it should be replaced. A ramp leads up
to the rest of the station.

transport "Modulator", the two-person tugboat "Space Rescue", the reconnaissance

A long red soft-bodied creature with many claw-tipped tentacles abruptly flings
itself at the side of the tank, its tentacles tapping at the glass, then it
withdraws.

help events
--
Star Conquest Help: Events
--
This game is Roleplay Enforced, which means that you should have your character
act in a manner consistent with the profile you will write in order to leave
cadethood.  This also means that your actions will have consequences, both
positive and negative, depending on those actions.  
There are four major types of event in Star Conquest:
1) Story Arc Plotlines
- These events are game-wide and will happen at specific points, when things
in-game set them up.  These have included First Contact with the Jinu, the
Renegade War, the Rebellion against the Outsiders and Diplomacy with the
Children of the Sun, to name a few.  
- Anyone who wishes to take part in these events will be able to join in, but
some parts may only be open to people who meet specific criteria. These events
will occur whether one particular person may want them to or not, but the
outcome may depend on player participation. 
2) Personal Event
- When the player of a character wants to enhance their roleplay in a way that
requires staff intervention but is not game-wide, the personal event comes into
play.  They are technically host-run, but will have the input of the player who
has specifically requested it.  They will usually be minor events in-universe,
but the more people involved, the greater the event will become.  
- These are covered by Policy 14, and will ONLY occur when a player has
specifically spoken to a staff member to request one, and this has been
discussed at length.  While a player can request specific things, it is
ultimately up to the staff to decide how the event is implemented, though we
will do what we can to keep things as requested while remaining in-theme with
the game universe.
3) Consequences
- NPCs will respond to the actions of a character or group of characters.  Meet
with a government official?  Maybe your actions can result in something that
will benefit your entire alliance!  Or maybe you attack another alliance's navy,
and the target blacklists you for a time, stopping you from accessing their
space.  These consequences will always make sense and will always be logical,
even if you are not aware of the entire sequence of events leading up to them.  
- Consequences to your character's IC actions will occur whether you want them
to or not, and if the actions of your character are extreme enough this will be
stressed ICly and eventually, if it continues to the point that your character
nears unplayability, you will be notified OOCly to make sure that you are aware
of the inevitable result.
4) Outside Interference
- Sometimes unexpected things can happen, things you never expected but that
affect you in minor (or possibly major) ways.  These 'Outside Interference'
events will happen unexpectedly and may alter your character without your
explicit consent.
- These events are OPT-IN only.  If you wish to be considered for participation
in such events, check your OPTIONS command, which will let you toggle whether
you are interested or not.  Unless you specifically opt-in using this command,
you will never have to worry about these events occuring to you.  These events
are random and unique, so even if you have opted in you may not experience
anything for quite some time.
NOTE: This is not something you can toggle freely at will. If you wish to
opt-in, please keep in mind that this is a one-time option.  If you subsequently
opt-out again, you are PERMANENTLY opted out.  You can never again opt in.
--
